name: Strategy, Products, Capability Work, and Teams
Informed Consent Form
markdown:
MIT Boeing - NASA ìLeadership at all Levelsî Pilot Program

Thank you for participating in the MIT - Boeing - NASA ìLeadership at all Levelsî pilot program.

Description of the Research

You are invited to participate in a Boeing-led research study on online open certificates focused on learner motivation and social engagement. The study consists of demographic data, online surveys, and learner interaction patterns on the learning platforms.

Risk and Benefits

There are no foreseeable risks involved in participating in this study. This research could expand our understanding on learner motivation and social engagement and will expand our understanding of learner engagement and inform the design of future online certificates. There are no direct benefits for participation.

Data Storage to Protect Confidentiality

Your data will be stored in a password protected electronic format.

How the Results Will Be Used:

The results will be used to explore learner trajectoryís and social networking engagement. The results might be presented or published in journals. All personal identifiable will be removed prior to any publication. Research question can be addressed to Michael Richey, PhD, Boeing Associate Technical Fellow (michael.c.richey@boeing.com) By clicking the ìI Agreeî box below, I give my consent to MIT to disclose data to the Boeing Research Team. By clicking on the ìI Do Not Agreeî button below, you will be unenrolled from this pilot program. (x)I Agree ()I Do Not Agree {{In Order to continue with this course you must agree to the terms above.}}

name: Question #1
markdown:
>>A companyís strategy: <<
(x) Defines the companyís purpose and objectives
(x) Limits a company's markets, products and geographical regions where it competes
(x) Defines a company's approach to gaining competitive advantage
(x) Defines the action programs that will be done to implement it
(x) Provides guidance for decision-making particularly priorities for resource allocation
(x) All of the above

name: Question #2
markdown:
>>Strategic thinking relies on two skills, namely thinking:<<
(x) Divergently and creatively
(x) Fast and slow
(x) Critically and creatively
(x) Convergently and critically

name: Question #3
markdown:
If youíre an engineer on a product team, you should:
(x) 	Focus entirely on your product and leave understanding your companyís strategy to the CEO and strategy team
(x) 	Understand your companyís strategy broadly but primarily focus on the product you are working on
(x) 	Understand your companyís strategy well enough to be able to trace its key elements to the products you are working on

name: Use this when ready: Learning to Lead
Public Only: Using the Discussion Forum
Leadership at all Levels Program Leadership
Academic Integrity and Rules of Conduct (1 min)
Academic Integrity and Rules of Conduct
Question #1
markdown:
What best describes the way that CRISPR has approached its strategy for creating new therapies, or ëproductsí?

(x) 	Maximize probability of developing a product successfully using a two-pronged approach.
( ) 	Targeting a large number of diseases simultaneously to minimize risk of an unviable product.
( ) 	Concentrating only on the in vivo approach because it has more future growth potential.
( ) 	They donít need to define a strategy for this ñ they can rely on their powerful technology.

[explanation]
Reading closely in the we see: 

"We are pursuing a two-pronged development strategy using both of the known gene editing approaches (ì in vivoî and ìex vivoî)."
[explanation]

name: Question #2
markdown:
What qualities or strengths does CRISPR Therapeutics believe it has that sets it apart and makes it a leader in this field?

( ) 	High cash inflows, investor confidence and significant funding sources to support R&D spending.
(x) 	Scientific expertise, product development strategy, partnerships and intellectual property
( ) 	A young, dynamic team of graduates from top universities that brings a fresh perspective to the field.
( ) 	Strategic engagements with regulators and government agencies that position them uniquely to bring the new science into active clinical use.

[explanation]
Reading Closely we see that CRISPR Therapeutics believes it has

"(a) highly experienced team, together with our scientific expertise, product development strategy, partnerships and intellectual property." as its strengths.
[explanation]

name: Understanding the Key Elements of Strategy
Understanding the Key Elements of Strategy
Question #4
How Strategy Is Made and How You Can Make It for Your Group (20 min)
Case: Kirk and the Squads at UFP
Question #1
markdown:
Why was Kirk initially reluctant to take charge of the squad?
( ) 	He didnít think his team members were very capable.
(x) 	Everyone on the team, including him, was new to the squad system.
( ) 	There was no defined product on which they were supposed to work.
( ) 	He was considering leaving UFP to join the competitors at RSE.com.

name: Question #2
markdown:
What did the VP give Kirk to help him get started in leading his new squad to success? 
( ) 	Additional time of 6 months to produce a working prototype.
( ) 	Additional priority access to company laboratory resources apart from what the team already had.
(x) 	Additional budget to hire up to two more team members.
( ) 	Additional products apart from Enterprise that the team could choose to work on.

name: Question #3
markdown:
Why was the strategic decision regarding optical technology important?
( ) 	They had the best in class optical technology and it was very important to maintain their technical leadership.
(x) 	Their competitors at RSE.com had already developed better optical technology which could help them win an upcoming government project bid.
( ) 	Optical technology cost the most to develop out of all their product components.

name: Case: The Birth of Amazon Web Services
Question #1
markdown:
According to the case, why did engineers at Amazon first start to write code in an API-based manner?
(x) 	They were trying to solve a problem with an existing service for external customers that was difficult to use.
( ) 	They were exploring new ways of doing their work in their free time.
( ) 	The company strategy required that they become better at using APIs in their work.
( ) 	Their competitors were doing it already, and they wanted to catch up.

[explanation]
There was a business opportunity for Amazon, if they could compartmentalize their e-commerce engine, they could offer it as a service to other retailers.
[explanation]

name: Question #2
markdown:
How did Amazon become ëquite goodí at running software infrastructure services?
( )	They committed significant funds and their best people to developing the capability as a future business opportunity.
(x)	Internal engineering teams needed infrastructure for their own projects, and the companyís fast growth meant they had to share common resources.
( )	They acquired a company that was already doing this at scale successfully.
( )	CEO Jeff Bezos announced during a company retreat that this was to be a priority.

name: Question #3
markdown:
Which of the following is truest of the strategic decision that led to the creation of AWS?
( ) 	It was part of Amazonís strategy from Day 1.
(x) 	It developed because of the identification of a key internal strength.
( ) 	It was made in response to a perceived weakness of Amazon as a tech leader.
( ) 	There was no strategic decision, it just happened.

[[(Method of Transfer)
Value Created
Output - Good or Service
]]
II.	A design created by a component engineering team.
[[Method of Transfer
Value Created
(Output - Good or Service)
]]
III.	Subscription to a delivery service, bought online.
[[(Method of Transfer)
Value Created
Output - Good or Service
]]
IV.	The capacity to transport items by road as and when required.
[[Method of Transfer
(Value Created)
Output - Good or Service
]]
V.	A package delivery service offered by a transportation company.
[[Method of Transfer
Value Created
(Output - Good or Service)
]]
VI.	A research paper written by a professor and a postdoctoral researcher.
[[Method of Transfer
Value Created
(Output - Good or Service)
]]

[[(Method of Transfer)
Value Created
Output - Good or Service
]]

Output - Good or Service

markdown: Labels 1 and 2 represent external interaction with accompanying systems. If 1 represents an ìenter pass codes to arm/disarmî interaction, and 2 represents a ìreceive alert for backup resources/respond with backup resourcesî interaction, pick from the labels below and fill in the two empty accompanying systemsí boxes. Box A: [[Sensors {{Sensors are not an accompanying system, they are part of the home security system. Sensors are not entering pass codes to arm and disarm the system. }} (Human Controller) {{ The human controller is the accompanying system that enters the pass codes to arm and disarm the system. }} Alarm Monitoring Company {{While the alarm monitoring company is an accompanying system, it is not the one entering pass codes to arm and disarm the system. }} Alarm {{The alarm is not an accompanying system, it is a part of the home security system. The alarm is not entering pass codes to arm and disarm the system.}} Touchpad {{The touch pad is not an accompanying system, it is a part of the home security system. The touch pad gets pass codes entered on it, but is not the one entering pass codes to arm and disarm the system. }} ]] Box B: [[Sensors{{Sensors are not an accompanying system, they are part of the home security system. Sensors are not receiving alerts for backup resources/responding with backup resources.}} Human Controller{{While the human controller is an accompanying system, it is not the one receiving alerts for backup resources/responding with backup resources.}} (Alarm Monitoring Company) {{The alarm monitoring company is the accompanying system that receives alerts for backup resources/responds with backup resources.}} Alarm {{The alarm is not an accompanying system, it is a part of the home security system. The alarm is not receiving alerts for backup resources/responding with backup resources.}} Touchpad {{The touch pad is not an accompanying system, it is a part of the home security system. The touchpad is not receiving alerts for backup resources/responding with backup resources.}} ]] ||Box A: Pick the accompanying system that is entering pass codes to arm and disarm the system. || ||Box B: Pick the accompanying system that receives alerts for backup resources and responds with backup resources.||

name: Question #2
markdown: Pick from the labels below and fill in the entitiesí boxes labeled A and B: Box A: The entity in the middle of the system [[Home Security System {{The home security system is the overall system we are decomposing into entities. }} Sensors {{While the home security system does have sensors, note the sensors interact only with the control panel. }} Doors {{Doors are not entities of the home security system ñ they are outside the system boundary. }} (Control Panel) {{The home security system has a control panel, and the control panel interacts with all other entities plus all the accompanying systems. }} Windows {{Windows are not entities of the home security system ñ they are outside the system boundary. }}]] Box B: The entity in upper left corner of the system [[Home Security System {{The home security system is the overall system we are decomposing into entities. }} (Sensors) {{The home security system has sensors, and sensors interact only with the control panel. }} Doors {{Doors are not entities of the home security system ñ they are outside the system boundary. }} Control Panel {{While the home security system does have a control panel, note the control panel interacts with all other entities plus also the accompanying systems. }} Windows {{Windows are not entities of the home security system ñ they are outside the system boundary. }} ]] ||Box A: Pick the entity of the home security system that is interacting with all other entities plus all the accompanying systems. || ||Box B: Pick the entity of the home security system that is only interacting with one other entity. ||

name: Question #3
markdown: >>How many external interfaces are there?<< (x) 2 {{Every external interaction that crosses the red dashed line defines an external interface. There are two external interfaces ñ one between the control panel and the human controller, and the second between the control panel and the alarm monitoring company.}} ( ) 3 {{Every external interaction that crosses the red dashed line defines an external interface. }} ( ) 4 {{Every external interaction that crosses the red dashed line defines an external interface. }} ( ) 6 {{Every external interaction that crosses the red dashed line defines an external interface. }} >>How many internal interfaces are there?<< (x) 2 {{Each internal interaction among the entities (i.e. within the red dashed line) defines an internal interface. There are two internal interfaces - one between the sensor and the control panel, and one between the alarm and the control panel. }} ( ) 3 {{Each internal interaction among the entities (i.e. within the red dashed line) defines an internal interface. }} ( ) 4 {{Each internal interaction among the entities (i.e. within the red dashed line) defines an internal interface. }} ( ) 6 {{Each internal interaction among the entities (i.e. within the red dashed line) defines an internal interface. }} ||Every external interaction that crosses the red dashed line defines an external interface.|| ||Each internal interaction among the entities (i.e. within the red dashed line) defines an internal interface. ||

Question #1
markdown:
>>Why is a pull system superior to a push system for knowledge work?<<

[x] A push system limits the overall performance of the work process
[x] A pull system sets clear limits on work-in-process accumulation and then, if the system hits one of those limits, use that information as a signal of an underlying problem 
[ ] There isnít a significant difference between a push system and a pull system {{selected: a pull system in an organization can improve task flow and prevent overload. A push system pushes work into the next step in the process whether the next person in line is ready for it or not.}}

||Constant overload and firefighting is the result of one of the systems.||
